abstracts.cdata!:
The National Irrigation Rehabilitation
            Project is assessed as unsatisfactory with unlikely
            sustainability. Several of the lessons learned include: a)
            up-front commitments on agriculture sector policy and
            related institutional reforms are needed to achieve
            successful irrigation investment projects; b) low irrigated
            farming system productivity and profitability inhibits the
            development of viable farmers organizations (FOs), and
            establishment of beneficiary- driven sustainable O&M
            arrangements; c) forming FOs and carrying out irrigation
            rehabilitation concurrently does not work well; d) the
            downstream impacts of schemes needs to be adequately
            analyzed in scheme selection, planning and design for future
            projects; e) to ensure effective implementation of
            irrigation rehabilitation it is essential to develop and
            enforce pragmatic civil works specifications, contract
            packaging, administration, and quality assurance systems
            suitable for rehabilitation; f) consideration should be
            given for a contractor pre-qualification system; g) the
            establishment of a maintenance fund to cover O&M costs
            with actual support from farmers has proved to be a possible
            solution for project sustainability; h) the Bank should
            elicit UN agency participation; and i) implementation
            management responsibility should be devolved to provinces
            instead of the national government.
